--- title: "Intro intro R" author: Raphael Rehms format: revealjs: scrollable: true theme: solarized # moon transition: slide footer: "Intro intro R" slide-number: c include-after-body: clean_title_page.html fontsize: 25pt highlight-style: github execute: echo: true freeze: auto editor: markdown: wrap: 72 --- # Orga ## Parts Combination of - Slides - "lecture like" - New content, Theoretical part - Exercises - Hands-on - Dedicated time during the course - "Interactive" # Intro ## Why R? Why R? - R is **open source** - All techniques for data analyses - State-of-the-art graphics capabilities - A platform for programming new statistical methods or analysis pipelines (in form of R-packages) ## Programming (in general) *"Good programmers are made, not born."* (Gerald M. Weinberg - The Psychology of Computer Programming) - consequence I train... - consequence II train... - consequence III train more Hands-on is important. Understanding is less that 30% ## R and R Studio Required tools for the course: - Programming language R - designed to make fast prototyping for statistical analysis - interpreted language - RStudio (optional, but recommended) - IDE tailored for `R` - Integrates a lot more (e.g. python, c++, etc.) ## R packages - `R` comes with many useful packages by default - However, the strength lies in the huge collection of external packages - Most popular and default: [**CRAN**](https://cran.r-project.org/) - Install new packages in R using either - using a command: - `install.packages("")` (e.g.`install.packages("mvtnorm")`) - RStudio - using built-in tools from the IDE # Basic operations ## Addition, subtraction, etc ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} 1+2 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 3 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} 1-2 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] -1 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} 1*2 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 2 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} 1/2 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 0.5 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} 1^2 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 1 ``` ::: ::: ::: callout-note What will happen? ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} 1/0 ``` ::: ::: ## Special symbols functions Special symbols ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} pi Inf ``` ::: Mathematical functions ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} exp(1) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 2.718282 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} log(1) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 0 ``` ::: ::: Special cases: - `NaN` is a data type that indicates an invalid number. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} log(-1) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] NaN ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} NaN + 1 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] NaN ``` ::: ::: - `NA` is a missing value. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} NA + 1 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] NA ``` ::: ::: - `NULL` means literally empty/nothing ## Assigning objects Assignment is done using `<-` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} x <- 1 y <- 2 x + y ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 3 ``` ::: ::: Alternatively, use `=` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} x = sqrt(2) y = sqrt(2) x * y ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 2 ``` ::: ::: [Look at environment pane in R Studio, what can you see?]{style="color:blue;"} ## Naming objects - Objects in `R` have to start with a letter Case sensitive ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} a <- 2 A <- 1 a-a ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 0 ``` ::: ::: Overwrite variables with old ones ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} a <- a + 1 ``` ::: Combination of words ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} variable_name <- 1 variable.name <- 1 variableName <- 1 ``` ::: ## Comments Sometimes it is useful, to comment code. Use a `#` to comment Standard: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} 1+1 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 2 ``` ::: ::: Comment a line (no output): ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # 1+1 ``` ::: Comment after an expression (only `1+1` gets evaluated): ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} 1+1 # +1 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 2 ``` ::: ::: ## Function calling So far we used expressions like `f(...)`. This is a **function**. E.g. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} exp(2) ``` ::: We call the function `exp` with a value of 2. Or the (natural) logarithm: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} log(exp(1)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 1 ``` ::: ::: We can specify the base as a *second argument*: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} log(2, 2) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 1 ``` ::: ::: ::: callout-note What will happen? ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} Log(Exp(1)) ``` ::: ::: ## Get documentation Access the documentation using - `` - type `?function_name` - use RStudio functionality E.g. documentation for `log()` reveals that we calculate the natural logarithm. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ?log log(x, base = exp(1)) ``` ::: ## Function calling cont'd You can ignore the argument name, when placements are clear. - We have done that for `exp` and `log` Hence, this here ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} log(2, 2) ``` ::: means, that we actually call ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} log(x=2, base=2) ``` ::: If you specify the argument, order does not matter. Example: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} log(base=3, x=2) log(3, 2) ``` ::: ::: callout-note What will happen? ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} log <- 1 log(log) ``` ::: ::: ## Basic (primitive) data types #### `numeric` A (floating point) number. We used this so far (default). `1.0, 1.34, -33, pi`
#### `logical` A binary data type. `TRUE, FALSE, T, F`
#### `integer` Can be specified using an "L". `1L, 100L, -99L`
#### `character` Represents letters OR sentences. `'a', "abc", "May the force be with you"` # Exercise 1 # Vectors ## Vectors You can *combine* single values to a *vector.* ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} a <- c(1,2,3,4) a ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 1 2 3 4 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} b <- c(TRUE, FALSE, TRUE) b ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] TRUE FALSE TRUE ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} c <- c("a", 'ab', "ab c") c ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "a" "ab" "ab c" ``` ::: ::: Many operations in R are *vectorized* ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} a + a ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 2 4 6 8 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} a * a ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 1 4 9 16 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} exp(a) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 2.718282 7.389056 20.085537 54.598150 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} -a ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] -1 -2 -3 -4 ``` ::: ::: ::: callout-note What will happen? ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} c("1",2,3) ``` ::: ::: ## Automatic recycling ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} a <- c(1,2,3,4) a + 1 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 2 3 4 5 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} b <- c(2,2) a + b ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 3 4 5 6 ``` ::: ::: ::: callout-warning Note the behavior for for vectors with different length! Example: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} a <- c(1,2,3) b <- c(1,2) a + b ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning in a + b: longer object length is not a multiple of shorter object length ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 2 4 4 ``` ::: ::: ::: ## Vector creation There are a lot of convenience functions to create vectors. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} c(1,2,3,4) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 1 2 3 4 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} 1:4 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 1 2 3 4 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} seq(4) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 1 2 3 4 ``` ::: ::: More complex ones: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} 4:-3 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 4 3 2 1 0 -1 -2 -3 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} seq(-10, 10, by = 2) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] -10 -8 -6 -4 -2 0 2 4 6 8 10 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} seq(-10, 10, length.out = 10) # vector of length 10 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] -10.000000 -7.777778 -5.555556 -3.333333 -1.111111 1.111111 [7] 3.333333 5.555556 7.777778 10.000000 ``` ::: ::: ## Select elements of a vector **Access elements of a vector using positional numbers within `[...]`:** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} x <- c(2,4,2,5) x[1] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 2 ``` ::: ::: Multiple elements ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} selection <- c(1,4) x[selection] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 2 5 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} x[c(1,4)] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 2 5 ``` ::: ::: Negative values will be excluded ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} x[-c(1,3)] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 4 5 ``` ::: ::: ::: callout-note What will happen? ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} x[1:5] x[-(5:10)] x[0] ``` ::: ::: ## Logical values for comparison Recall the very most basic data type `logical`, i.e. `TRUE` and `FALSE`. - We can create such an object by comparison: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} 1 == 2 # lhs equal rhs? ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] FALSE ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} 1 != 2 # lhs unequal rhs? ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] TRUE ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} 1 > 2 # lhs larger rhs? ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] FALSE ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} 1 >= 2 # lhs larger or equal rhs? ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] FALSE ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} 1 < 2 # lhs less than rhs? ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] TRUE ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} 1 <= 2 # lhs less or equal than rhs? ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] TRUE ``` ::: ::: Swap value: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} !TRUE ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] FALSE ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} !FALSE ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] TRUE ``` ::: ::: ::: callout-note What will happen? ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} 1 == "1" 1 != NaN NA == NA # we will learn the solution in a few slides ``` ::: ::: ## Filter elements of a vector Comparison operators are vectorized: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} c(T,F,T) == c(F,F,T) # element-wise comparison ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] FALSE TRUE TRUE ``` ::: ::: Check condition on a numeric vector ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} x <- c(2,4,2,5) position_two <- x == 2 # logical vector showing, where the condition holds position_two ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] TRUE FALSE TRUE FALSE ``` ::: ::: **Use logical values to filter a vector.** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} x[position_two] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 2 2 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # or dictly x[x == 2] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 2 2 ``` ::: ::: Filter for values less than 3 ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} x[x < 3] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 2 2 ``` ::: ::: ## Combine filters with `&` and `|` Combination operations... ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} TRUE & TRUE ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] TRUE ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} FALSE & TRUE ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] FALSE ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} TRUE | TRUE ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] TRUE ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} FALSE | TRUE ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] TRUE ``` ::: ::: ...or vectorized ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} x <- c(T,F,T,F) y <- c(T,T,F,F) x & y ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] TRUE FALSE FALSE FALSE ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} x | y ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] TRUE TRUE TRUE FALSE ``` ::: ::: Use this to filter a vector for multiple conditions ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} x[(x < 5) & (x > 2)] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` logical(0) ``` ::: ::: ## Assign new values in a vector We can assign new values to a vector using a combination of selection and assignment ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} x <- 1:5 x[1] <- 2 x ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 2 2 3 4 5 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} x[x > 3] <- -99 x ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 2 2 3 -99 -99 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} x[-1] <- 100 x ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 2 100 100 100 100 ``` ::: ::: ::: callout-note What will happen? ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} x[100] <- 1 ``` ::: ::: ## Vector operations ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} x <- c(1,1,2,3) length(x) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 4 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} append(x, c(1,2,3)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 1 1 2 3 1 2 3 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} rev(x) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 3 2 1 1 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} sort(x) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 1 1 2 3 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} unique(x) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 1 2 3 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} sum(x) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 7 ``` ::: ::: # Exercise 2 # Complex structures ## Factors Consider a vector, that represents a categorical variable. Let's say colors. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} colors <- c("blue", "red", "blue", "red", "green", "black", "green", "white") colors ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "blue" "red" "blue" "red" "green" "black" "green" "white" ``` ::: ::: We cast `colors` into a factor now: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} colors <- as.factor(colors) colors ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] blue red blue red green black green white Levels: black blue green red white ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} levels(colors) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "black" "blue" "green" "red" "white" ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} as.numeric(colors) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 2 4 2 4 3 1 3 5 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} class(colors) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "factor" ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} typeof(colors) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "integer" ``` ::: ::: Hence, a vector of integeres where each value corresponds to a character value. ## Complex data structures ![from *Ceballos and Cardiel, (2013). Data structure â€“ First Steps in R. Retreived 25-11-2018 from http:// venus.ifca.unican.es/ Rintro.2024*](dataStructuresNew.png)
**Use `str(...)` to inspect the structure of complex data types!** ## Vector, Matrix, Array We already got vectors. Lets combine them: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} x <- 1:4 (x_rbind <- cbind(x,x)) # 4 rows, 2 columns ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` x x [1,] 1 1 [2,] 2 2 [3,] 3 3 [4,] 4 4 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} (x_cbind <- rbind(x,x)) # 2 rows, 4 columns ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [,1] [,2] [,3] [,4] x 1 2 3 4 x 1 2 3 4 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} dim(x_rbind) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 4 2 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} dim(x_cbind) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 2 4 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} nrow(x_rbind) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 4 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} ncol(x_rbind) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 2 ``` ::: ::: ## Vector, Matrix, Array cont'd We can define a matrix using the `matrix` function: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} matrix(1:6, nrow = 3, ncol = 2) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [,1] [,2] [1,] 1 4 [2,] 2 5 [3,] 3 6 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} matrix(1:6, nrow = 3, ncol = 2, byrow = T) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [,1] [,2] [1,] 1 2 [2,] 3 4 [3,] 5 6 ``` ::: ::: **Arrays as a generalization with multiple dimensions** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} array(1:12, dim = c(3,2,2)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` , , 1 [,1] [,2] [1,] 1 4 [2,] 2 5 [3,] 3 6 , , 2 [,1] [,2] [1,] 7 10 [2,] 8 11 [3,] 9 12 ``` ::: ::: This is also sometimes called a *tensor*. ## Select/filter elements on Arrays As vectors, we can select and filter. Seperate dimensions with a `,`, i.e. `[... , ...]` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} (m <- matrix(1:6, nrow = 3, ncol = 2)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [,1] [,2] [1,] 1 4 [2,] 2 5 [3,] 3 6 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} m[2,2] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 5 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} m[nrow(m), ncol(m) ] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 6 ``` ::: ::: Defining no entry will return the full dimension: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} m[2,] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 2 5 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} m[,1] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 1 2 3 ``` ::: ::: ::: callout-note What will happen? ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} m[1,,2] m[10] ``` ::: ::: ## List A list is a collection of elements. These elements could be any object. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} (l <- list(1, "2", 1:3, list(m))) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [[1]] [1] 1 [[2]] [1] "2" [[3]] [1] 1 2 3 [[4]] [[4]][[1]] [,1] [,2] [1,] 1 4 [2,] 2 5 [3,] 3 6 ``` ::: ::: Access elements of a list with `[[...]]`. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} l[[2]] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "2" ``` ::: ::: A sub-list can be accessed with `[...]`. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} l[1:3] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [[1]] [1] 1 [[2]] [1] "2" [[3]] [1] 1 2 3 ``` ::: ::: ## List cont'd You can define names for lists: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} l <- list(slot1 = 1:3, slot2 = c("a", "b"), slot3 = l) names(l) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "slot1" "slot2" "slot3" ``` ::: ::: Access list elements using the name and a `$`: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} l$slot3 # return the original list l before overwriting it ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [[1]] [1] 1 [[2]] [1] "2" [[3]] [1] 1 2 3 [[4]] [[4]][[1]] [,1] [,2] [1,] 1 4 [2,] 2 5 [3,] 3 6 ``` ::: ::: Delete elements by assigning a `NULL` to a slot ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} l[2:3] <- NULL l ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` $slot1 [1] 1 2 3 ``` ::: ::: ## Data Frame A data frame is basically a list, where each element is a vector of the same length. However, it implements function to handle it as a matrix. Let's define a data set representing cars: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} col <- as.factor(c("blue", "red", "blue", "red", "green", "black", "green", "white")) pri <- c(10, 20, 9, 50, 0.4, 15, 160, 60) * 1000 is_el <- c(F,F,F,T,F,T,F,T) car_ds <- data.frame(color = col, price = pri, is_electric = is_el) car_ds ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` color price is_electric 1 blue 10000 FALSE 2 red 20000 FALSE 3 blue 9000 FALSE 4 red 50000 TRUE 5 green 400 FALSE 6 black 15000 TRUE 7 green 160000 FALSE 8 white 60000 TRUE ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} str(car_ds) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 'data.frame': 8 obs. of 3 variables: $ color : Factor w/ 5 levels "black","blue",..: 2 4 2 4 3 1 3 5 $ price : num 10000 20000 9000 50000 400 15000 160000 60000 $ is_electric: logi FALSE FALSE FALSE TRUE FALSE TRUE ... ``` ::: ::: ## Data Frame cont'd We can work on a data set as we work with a matrix ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # All rows with red cars car_ds[car_ds$color == "red", ] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` color price is_electric 2 red 20000 FALSE 4 red 50000 TRUE ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # price of all black cars car_ds[car_ds$color == "black", "price"] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 15000 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # set a new price for the last car in the ds car_ds[8, 2] <- 600 car_ds ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` color price is_electric 1 blue 10000 FALSE 2 red 20000 FALSE 3 blue 9000 FALSE 4 red 50000 TRUE 5 green 400 FALSE 6 black 15000 TRUE 7 green 160000 FALSE 8 white 600 TRUE ``` ::: ::: ## More on data structures - A data frame behaves like a matrix. - However, keep in mind that it is actually a list. We can easily prove that: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} is.list(car_ds) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] TRUE ``` ::: ::: Use `str(...)` to check the data structure of *any* object: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} str(car_ds) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 'data.frame': 8 obs. of 3 variables: $ color : Factor w/ 5 levels "black","blue",..: 2 4 2 4 3 1 3 5 $ price : num 10000 20000 9000 50000 400 15000 160000 600 $ is_electric: logi FALSE FALSE FALSE TRUE FALSE TRUE ... ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} m <- matrix(1:4, ncol = 2) str(m) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` int [1:2, 1:2] 1 2 3 4 ``` ::: ::: ## Load data We can load a data set from a package using `data(...)`. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} data("iris", package = "datasets") # look in the environment variables ``` ::: We can load data from files. Use `read.table(...)`, or wrapper functions with reasonable default values. E.g. We can read a file directly from the web: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} d <- read.csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/vincentarelbundock/Rdatasets/master/csv/datasets/mtcars.csv") head(d) # show the first few lines of a data set ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` rownames mpg cyl disp hp drat wt qsec vs am gear carb 1 Mazda RX4 21.0 6 160 110 3.90 2.620 16.46 0 1 4 4 2 Mazda RX4 Wag 21.0 6 160 110 3.90 2.875 17.02 0 1 4 4 3 Datsun 710 22.8 4 108 93 3.85 2.320 18.61 1 1 4 1 4 Hornet 4 Drive 21.4 6 258 110 3.08 3.215 19.44 1 0 3 1 5 Hornet Sportabout 18.7 8 360 175 3.15 3.440 17.02 0 0 3 2 6 Valiant 18.1 6 225 105 2.76 3.460 20.22 1 0 3 1 ``` ::: ::: Note, that we can also use this to read a data set from a local directory! To do that we have to specify either the full path or define the path from the **working directory**. Use `getwd(...)` and `setwd(...)` to get or set the current working directory. See next slide for an example. ## Save data sets Consider a data set, you have worked with. You can save it using write functions. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} write.csv(car_ds, file = "example_data.csv") # we save our data set in the current working directory ``` ::: We can again read the data as a new object: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} d_loaded <- read.csv("example_data.csv") all.equal(car_ds,d_loaded) # test whether 2 (more complex) R object are the same ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "Names: 3 string mismatches" [2] "Length mismatch: comparison on first 3 components" [3] "Component 1: 'current' is not a factor" [4] "Component 2: Modes: numeric, character" [5] "Component 2: target is numeric, current is character" [6] "Component 3: Modes: logical, numeric" [7] "Component 3: target is logical, current is numeric" ``` ::: ::: [**We can read other files as well. E.g. excel, SPSS, SAS, etc.**]{style="color:blue;"} There are a lot of packages to do that. [I use the function `load(...)` from the `rio` package that tries to unify a lot of different formats.]{style="color:rgba(255, 99, 71, 0.5);"}) ## Save and load R objects So far, we only worked with data frames for read and write operations. We can save general `R` objects using `save(...)` and `load(...)` using the `.RData` format. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} a_list <- list(a = 42, data = iris, comment = "whatever") save(a_list, file = "example_object.RData") load("example_object.RData") ``` :::

<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
